question: Show that the Modulus Function $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ given by $f(x)=|x|$, is neither one-one nor onto, where $|x|$ is $x$, if $x$ is positive or $0$ and $|x|$ is $-x$, if $x$ is negative.
solution:
$f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is given by,
$f(x)=|x|=\begin{cases}x,&\text{if } x\ge 0\\-x,&\text{if } x<0\end{cases}$

It is seen that $f(-1) = |-1| = 1$ and $f(1) = |1| = 1$.

$\therefore f(-1) = f(1)$, but $-1 \neq 1$.

$\therefore f$ is not one-one.

Now, consider $-1 \in \mathbb{R}$.

It is known that $f(x) = |x|$ is always non-negative. Thus, there does not exist any element $x$ in domain $\mathbb{R}$ such that $f(x) = |x| = -1$.

$\therefore f$ is not onto.

Hence, the modulus function is neither one-one nor onto.
